  • core
  • Chapter 14: Specifications
  • Value Holsters

To manage requests for compilation to Inter.

  • §3. Conversions
  • §4. Holstering data

§1. 

    enum INTER_DATA_VHMODE from 1
    enum INTER_VAL_VHMODE
    enum INTER_VOID_VHMODE
    enum NO_VHMODE

    typedef struct value_holster {
        int vhmode_wanted;
        int vhmode_provided;
        inter_t val1, val2;
    } value_holster;

The structure value_holster is accessed in 14/cfs, 17/ts, 25/ci, 25/ciac, 25/cii, 26/iti and here.

§2. 

    value_holster Holsters::new(int vhm) {
        value_holster vh;
        vh.val1 = 0; vh.val2 = 0;
        vh.vhmode_wanted = vhm;
        vh.vhmode_provided = NO_VHMODE;
        if (vhm == NO_VHMODE) internal_error("can't want NO_VHMODE");
        return vh;
    }

The function Holsters::new is used in 5/nv (§25), 12/is (§7), 12/ca (§5), 12/dtd (§7), 13/rsfk (§4), 14/cfs (§9), 15/epv (§2), 24/pb (§14), 25/ci (§3.1.1, §3.2.3.3.1.3), 25/cp (§6), 26/iti (§9), 27/is (§31.1), 27/ei (§5).

§3. Conversions. 

    int Holsters::data_acceptable(value_holster *vh) {
        if (vh == NULL) internal_error("no VH");
        if ((vh->vhmode_wanted == INTER_DATA_VHMODE) ||
            (vh->vhmode_wanted == INTER_VAL_VHMODE)) return TRUE;
        return FALSE;
    }

    void Holsters::to_val_mode(value_holster *vh) {
        if (vh == NULL) internal_error("no VH");
        switch (vh->vhmode_provided) {
            case INTER_DATA_VHMODE:
                Emit::val(K_value, vh->val1, vh->val2);
                break;
            case INTER_VOID_VHMODE:
                internal_error("impossible conversion");
                break;
            case NO_VHMODE:
                vh->val1 = LITERAL_IVAL; vh->val2 = 0;
                Emit::val(K_value, vh->val1, vh->val2);
                break;
        }
        vh->vhmode_provided = INTER_VAL_VHMODE;
    }

The function Holsters::data_acceptable is used in 13/rsfk (§4), 14/rv (§24.1, §24.2, §24.3, §24.3.1), 15/ep (§11), 15/vp (§11), 17/ts (§8, §8.1), 17/rs (§5, §12, §12.1.1), 27/ei (§5).

The function Holsters::to_val_mode is used in 5/nv (§25), 13/rsfk (§4), 14/cfs (§7).

§4. Holstering data. 

    void Holsters::holster_pair(value_holster *vh, inter_t v1, inter_t v2) {
        if (vh == NULL) internal_error("no VH");
        vh->val1 = v1; vh->val2 = v2;
        vh->vhmode_provided = INTER_DATA_VHMODE;
    }

    void Holsters::unholster_pair(value_holster *vh, inter_t *v1, inter_t *v2) {
        if (vh == NULL) internal_error("no VH");
        if (vh->vhmode_provided != INTER_DATA_VHMODE) {
            if (vh->vhmode_provided != NO_VHMODE)
                if (problem_count == 0) internal_error("errant DV");
            vh->val1 = LITERAL_IVAL; vh->val2 = 0;
            vh->vhmode_provided = INTER_DATA_VHMODE;
        }
        *v1 = vh->val1; *v2 = vh->val2;
    }

The function Holsters::holster_pair is used in 5/nv (§25.1), 13/rsfk (§4), 14/rv (§24.1, §24.3), 15/ep (§11), 15/vp (§11), 17/rs (§12), 27/ei (§5).

The function Holsters::unholster_pair is used in 5/nv (§25), 13/rsfk (§4), 14/cfs (§9), 15/epv (§2.1), 26/iti (§9), 27/ei (§5).
